text: for thousands of years farmers in the
Fertile Nile Delta have dealt with the
vagaries of weather periodic flooding
locust swarms and other biblical plagues
but farmers here now face a different
kind of calamity kyros urban sprawl is
devouring what little arable farmland
there is in this mostly desert country
to lot mohammed is one of the last
farmers in this area 30 miles north of
Cairo his sweet potato fields now look
like a trash littered vacant plot well
cotton linen bevel heavy is the law I
face many obstacles while farming my
land since it is surrounded by houses
first there are no canals here for my
land so I have to bring the water from
that house over there which cost me a
lot of money as countries around the
world try to ensure future food supply
few problems loom larger than the
population boom the water scarce regions
of the Middle East and North Africa
currently the Regents depend on the rest
of the world for more than half of their
food in Egypt recent spikes and global
food prices have raised alarm bells and
driven home the need to bolster domestic
production everything has gone up the
thing that costs five pounds now costs
10 pounds and what costs 10 pounds now
costs 15 and what about the bread
disaster last April riots broke out due
to shortages of government subsidized
breads sad of the shadow and I mean what
shall we do we have to buy you think my
children are not going to eat or shall
they just cover themselves and sleep
forever
Egypt's response to the problem lies
deep in the Sahara Desert where the
temperature often tops 110 degrees this
green oasis called Tushka is Egypt's
model farm of the future made possible
by fertilizers and now river water
pumped in across 150 miles of canals
Mohamed naggy Mohammed is chief engineer
of Tushka farms pub on the headland
bottle building inshallah we have to
search for those seeds which are going
to give us a good crop so we can solve
one of our problems which is our current
food crisis was a demo good when the
Egyptian government unveiled the toshka
farms project in 1997 officials
predicted it would be an accomplishment
on par with the pyramids with half a
million acres of farmland and thriving
communities so far though a few people
have moved here and only 30,000 acres
have been planted critics of the project
have called it a risky investment and an
unwise use of limited water resources
but mr. Mohammed remains hopeful that
pushka farms can reinvigorate Egyptian
agriculture and food production I'm
Lebanon wada lady knows what's up we are
making a lot of profit here and also our
government is supporting us with all the
facilities we need and there's no
problem there's no problem well Fishman
shake it would go and okay Bob
